docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Eliot Spitzer is expected to lay out his plan to rein in Medicaid and other health care spending, setting the stage for a battle with politically powerful health care providers and unions.

headline.main: Spitzer to Outline Plans for Cuts in Health Spending

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush’s new health care proposals would be unlikely to reduce the ranks of the uninsured very much and could actually increase their numbers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The unexpected revenue will allow the mayor to cut taxes and set aside money for future expenses.

headline.main: Mayor Sees $3.9 Billion Surplus Fed by Booming Real Estate Market
headline.print_headline: Mayor Projects $3.9 Billion Surplus Fed by a Booming Real Estate Market

docs.snippet: The unexpected revenue will allow the mayor to cut taxes and set aside money for future expenses.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders of the State Senate offered a $450 million plan yesterday to increase publicly financed health care programs for the uninsured. The plan would make 140,000 uninsured people eligible for programs like Medicaid and insurance plans for children. It would leave an estimated 260,000 residents without health insurance, but Donald E. Williams, the Senate president, said it was a “first step” toward a universal health care program. Compiled by Thomas J. Lueck.
docs.snippet: Democratic leaders of the State Senate offered a $450 million plan yesterday to increase publicly financed health care programs for the uninsured. The plan would make 140,000 uninsured people eligible for programs like Medicaid and insurance plans...

docs.lead_paragraph: “If people in Washington are serious about dealing with the uninsured, here is a serious idea for them to consider,” President Bush said of his plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: While President Bush was promoting his health initiatives at a roundtable at St. Luke's Hospital in Lee's Summit, Mo., today, he kind of forgot how many workers now pay for their health care benefits. (See the line we've boldfaced below.)

headline.main: Bush on Free Health Care Benefits

docs.abstract: President Bush suggests today that workers with employer-based health coverage get their benefits for free.
docs.snippet: President Bush suggests today that workers with employer-based health coverage get their benefits for free.

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students consider word choice in the State of the Union address and investigate the topics he raises by exploring the New York Times special section on the speech. For homework, they rewrite the opening paragraphs of the speech to emphasize issues of their choosing.
